title-group.article-title: The New Deal for Young People Five Years On

abstract.p: The New Deal for Young People is the major welfare-to-work programme in the UK. It is a mandatory multistage policy targeted at 18- to 24-year-old unemployed people. This paper investigates the long-term effectiveness of the programme in terms of enhancing the (re-)employment probability of participating men. It exploits the eligibility rule to identify a suitable counterfactual relying upon a simple regression discontinuity design. The combination of job-search assistance, training, wage subsidies and job experience enhances employability by about 4.6 per cent and this effect lasts over different cohorts.

p.mixed-citation: The author would like to thank Erich Battistin, Richard Blundell, Pedro Carneiro, Hideiko Ichimura, an editor and two anonymous referees for useful comments and suggestions.

JSA is the only unemployment insurance targeted at the group of interest in this work. In order to be eligible, an unemployed person has to be willing and able to work (previous employment history is not required); before the introduction of the New Deal, only weak requirements were imposed to ensure receipt of JSA in principle indefinitely.
The sanction for non-compliers is the withdrawal of benefit, at least temporarily.

The NDYP is basically the only programme available to young men, whereas there are other programmes for women which are not easily distinguishable and which are therefore a source of potential identification problems. Furthermore, most of the treated individuals (75 per cent) are male.

The starting date of the JSA should coincide with the start of the unemployment period. The 18- month cut-off point is due to the fact that the control group that will be exploited later would enter an ALMP after 18 months in open unemployment. A shorter period would not consider those participants who take the education and training option (see Section H).
This is due to the availability of data.

A limited number of unemployed people, not included in the analysis, can access the programme earlier than the sixth month. This particular group is composed of ex-offenders, disabled people and unemployed people lacking very basic skills (with reading and writing difficulties).
This is not always the case since certain units of delivery tend to favour a particular option.

Such a subsidy seems quite generous when compared with the sort of hourly rate (close to the minimum wage) a typical participant would get. In a crude computation, the weekly subsidy plus the one-off payment would amount to about 50 per cent of weekly pay for a minimum-wage worker; however, the £750 has to compensate for the loss of production due to the minimum one-day-a-week training. Under very simple assumptions (perfectly competitive markets), £750 would not be enough to compensate for that loss. In fact, taking the latter into account, the subsidy would be no greater than 30 per cent, although this is still generous. However, job turnover could itself be quite costly, making such an option not as appealing as it looks at first glance. This point seems to be confirmed by the low take-up rate in the data - only a sixth of those entering an option go for the subsidised job.
Formal derivation and technical details of identification and possible estimation strategies are available in De Giorgi (2005).
The actions of potential participants before and after the programme, during the first six months of unemployment, are not consistent with any sort of anticipatory behaviour (De Giorgi, 2005).
The vast majority (about 90 per cent) of the treated would have completed their first option by that time.

There may be anticipatory behaviour in the control groups, given that they are offered a similar programme after 18 months in open unemployment. Concern regarding this possibility can be dismissed by comparing the behaviour of 25- to 30-year-olds before and after the programme.
This limit arises from the availability of data.
This refers to specifications (i) and (ii) since the higher-order terms in specification (iii) are statistically insignificant.
Obviously, this would impose a much stronger identification structure - for example, constant treatment effects.

It is worth mentioning, as pointed out by a referee, that such displacement might also arise from enhanced job search. However, in this respect, it might simply be that the matching function is improved and vacancies are filled more efficiently, without affecting the outcome of the control groups.

This computation does not involve any steady-state analysis; it only applies the point estimate (Table 1, column (ii)), plus or minus twice the standard error, to the pool of unemployed men (about 560,000) involved in the programme up to December 2001.
Confirming earlier findings from Blundell et al. (2004).
Unfortunately, the available data do not permit such analysis.
